docs.lead_paragraph: The financially ailing HIP Health Plan of New Jersey, the state's fourth-largest health maintenance organization, has been placed under state supervision in an attempt to improve its fiscal standing. The Acting State Insurance Commissioner, Jaynee LaVecchia, said on Monday that regulators are now overseeing virtually every aspect of HIP's financial operations and that a state-appointed supervisor will oversee day-to-day operations.

headline.main: Metro Business; Watching New Jersey HIP

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is an old joke told by statistics professors about a fellow who has his feet in the oven and his head in the freezer: on average, he feels fine. The lesson is that statistics can be wildly misleading if they are not put into perspective. It's a point that is often lost in the popular notion that female entrepreneurship is a robust and increasingly significant segment of the American economy.

headline.main: Big in Small Business, Straining to Grow

docs.abstract: Jane Fritsch reports on mixed success female entrepreneurs are having, with more and more women starting, or running, their own businesses; women now own nearly 40 percent of 23 mlllion businesses in United States; female-owned businesses employ more than 18 million people, generate more than $2 trillion in sales annually and have obtained more bank loans than ever before; growth of employment by female-owned businesses is greater than natl average in nearly every region of country and in nearly every major industry; there is a gloomy statistic, however: women get less than 2 percent of venture capital invested each year in American businesses (Special section on entrepreneurship in America) (M)
docs.snippet: THERE is an old joke told by statistics professors about a fellow who has his feet in the oven and his head in the freezer: on average, he feels fine.    The lesson is that statistics can be wildly misleading if they are not put into perspective....

docs.lead_paragraph: THE Manhattan woman was in the first trimester of pregnancy with her first child when she decided how she wanted the baby delivered. She had read about childbirth in pregnancy books, heard war stories from friends and relatives and feared that she could not endure whatever labor pain she might have before the epidural kicked in. She told her doctor that when her pregnancy was full term, she wanted a Caesarean section. ''I spent a long time counseling her,'' said Dr. Andrei Rebarber, her obstetrician at New York University Medical Center. He told her that she had a greater chance for complications, including hemorrhage, infection and death, from a Caesarean section than from vaginal delivery. ''I told her I won't do a Caesarean section without a medical indication. I feel that it's unethical.''

headline.main: Doctors Report Rise in Elective Caesareans

docs.abstract: Some doctors say more women are asking for Caesarean sections, even when they are not necessary; doctors are sharply divided on how to respond; turnaround is being driven by several recent reports that question safety of vaginal deliveries in certain circumstances; British Medical Journal cites as other reasons medical avances like local anesthesia that have made Caesarean sections safer, and evidence that long, difficult vaginal deliveries can cause stress incontinence and other pelvic damage to mother, and cerebral palsy or even death to baby; chart (M)
